comments.commentBody:
My life was enabled by high quality low cost higher education from the 1960's. My parents were 2nd and 4th grade educated and yet with the help of a honors public high school (Lowell) and a quality university (San Francisco State) and University of Colorado, I have a PhD and have had a great life as a professor, consultant, and public policy person.
Yet today children like me have no such opportunity.
To me the biggest cause is the corruption of Congress wherein they only serve the wealthy who pay for their elections. State level is similar but has a different cause as well, Medicaid.
In Colorado, and most state, health care took just one percent of state budgets in the 1970's since corporations paid for everyone's health care. Higher Education got about 25 percent of general state taxes and tuition was low enough to provide access with limited jobs and debt.
Now Medicaid takes 25% of state budgets and tuition pays for higher education. This is not only a cause of inequality but an eating of our seat corn for the future. All to make billionaires more money, and congress more money as well. shame on them!. For profit should not exist in higher education, K12 education, or health care. That greed is killing America. And I am a business professor who used to believe in American capitalism until I saw it start destroying our children and our future.

I'd argue that it is precisely this kind of visionary thought that has reduced human poverty, not increased it. And arguments against thought are I suppose as old as thought itself. It will never do us any good, they say -- even as they use the products of thought to send their post decrying it around the world.

Try looking at your post from the perspective of a 22nd century historian. He and his robot will be in stitches.

Bravo, MLP.  And have you noticed that while we are fantasizing and arguing about machines that will duplicate human experience, the machines we are actually using and building are designed explicitly to make us more predictable, more manipulatable, & more profitable--more machine-like, in fact?
You are - rightly - arguing for the "human" in human nature. Thank you.

Here is a radical idea: instead of striving for friendship with computers, how about striving for friendship and solidarity with other human beings? How about cultivating a sense of empathy for human beings living in a society in which the rich are becoming obscenely richer and everybody else poorer, while those at the bottom are increasingly bereft of all hope? How about struggling to build a more just and humane society for beings that we know are real people instead of frittering precious time away speculating about implausible scenarios from bad science fiction? Such frittering and aimless speculation is yet another symptom of the decadence of late stage capitalism.

Good try, Jim.  Generally, the 'Starbuck Lounges' are actually student spaces that would exist anyway, with a Starbucks coffee operating within as an outside vendor.  The college earns money by renting out space to such vendors.  Yes, when a student chooses to pay $3 for a coffee, they are in part paying for their own lounge space.  Meals--again, the cost of meals is paid for by students.  There are usually several meal plans to choose from, and those who live off campus can cook whatever they please.  The money that is spent on women's sports is laughable.  There are also plenty of sports played by males that generate no money, such as wrestling, archery, golf, diving and swimming.  Incidentally, with the exception of wrestling, women play these sports as well, so the 'loss' you refer to is shared by both male and female students.  The college does NOT pay for study abroad programs, and in fact, they also generate money for the college, and only students who wish to participate do so.  I've been to a few Ivy and State gyms.  Don't recall any spas there.  Suite living allows fewer bathroom/shower installations, thereby cutting costs of dorm construction.  When a student graduates and where a student chooses to go to school is again a CHOICE of the student and his/her family, and again, has nothing to do with the rising price of higher education.  How about the astronomical pay for MBA's, marketing teams, football teams and college presidents?!  There you go. . .
Yes, all indications are that he or she will do better with that 4-year degree.

About 50 years ago when I first had a chance to read the WSJ, the editorials at that time were about inflation and the debasing of the dollar. Inflation was defined as an increase in the supply of money against the amount of gold available. Then some years later it got changed to an increase in wages and prices, which was related to the unions who were quite successful then at getting good wages and benefits. That is the definition we have now. Obviously it hurts those that have not got increases in incomes as it is today, but it is the wages of the 10% that are inflationary, not the wages of the working class.

Then in the 2000s, the WSJ began targeting Freddie and Fannie as being responsible for economic travails. However the findings of the Angelides
Commission showed that to be false, but the financial publications kept warning about inflation, and related it to government spending, and went about convincing people that the government budget was like your personal one, and you could not keep spending. This has been the big noise since the Regan statement about government being the problem.

The inflation fear carries over from the German money printing of the 1920s, to today. We have seen deflation however, and how much personal wealth that has destroyed, and that seems to be what the conservatives want, in order to shrink the government, and increase the influence of the wealthy.

Nice.  See also Rudyard Kipling's great story "The SHip who Found Herself" in which a steamship on her maiden voyage brings all her works and engines and  processes, her human crew and their knowledge, together to finally create a single being.
Men routinely refer to machines, autos especially, as she. The possibility of a romantic attachment begins when she laughs at our jokes.

Relationships bordering on emotional between people and machines are not limited to new technology.   For example, anyone familiar with steam locomotives knows that even supposedly identical ones had different personalities, so much so that drivers bonded more closely with some engines more than others.

The silver lining is that current Fed Chair Janet Yellen was concerned about plunging economic activity and unemployment in 2008. I hope that Yellen will be able to dampen the inflation fears of the Fed's conservatives until the economy is on firmer footing.

As for the inflation fears of the Fed in 2008: it is sad that we are often doomed to repeat the errors of history. We were fortunate, however, that Ben Bernanke-- with his superb understanding of the economic history of the Great Depression-- was at the helm of the Fed in 2008. Without Bernanke, things would likely have been far worse.

This is a foolish position. You are being suckered in by those who want to destroy Israel.

If you really want to contribute to the effort for peace in the Mid East, bring pressure to bear upon the Palestinians and Arabs to accept the Jewish State of Israel and stop teaching hatred to their children. If they had accepted the two-state solution and partition plan from the UN in 1947-8 instead of making war on Israel, there would now be a thriving Palestinian State in place.

And how would exercising pressure on the "willing party" make the life of Israelis better? This defies basic logic. If you want to make the peace agreement possible - you should put pressure on the "unwilling party". For that, me and my children will be forever thankful.

Lara Friedman makes a very important point: what the Palestinians do or fail to do does not absolve Israel of the responsibility to refrain from actions that make peace impossible.

I want to do everything I can to support the majority of Israelis who want peace, a better life for their children and a state of normalcy and acceptance that they have not experienced in years. If BDS, despite its large anti Israel membership, is the best way to achieve that, I will support it.

replies.commentBody:
Sorry but the global consensus of archaeologists (including the leading Israeli archaeologists) & experts in Near East history is that there was no Exodus , no Joshua invasion of Canaan & that the biblical Israelites were native Canaanites who lived in the highlands of Canaan. ie. No Moses , no covenant , no promised land.

As to Abraham ,he is also a myth. Bible scholars agree that the 2 references to him being from Ur date to the Helenic period(300 BC or later). That he met a Philistine king & used camels as beasts of burden 1000 yrs before that was possible is not a problem for the uninformed. As is the consensus of experts that the United Monarchy never was.ie. In the 10th century BC, Judea was a very sparsely populated outback of 23 villages while Samaria had 235 villages & towns with 8-10x the population & yet most people lived on the coastal plain or fertile Jezreel valley.

We need to separate the myths from facts. Justifying the ethnic cleansing of Palestine on the fairy tale of the Passover is equivalent to celebrating Easter based on the Easter bunny. ie. Jesus was a Torah-observant Jew who believed in Mosaic law not the stuff that Paul & later writers cooked up.

comments.commentBody:
Didn't pay much attention during bible studies, did you? if you want to use the Bible as a reference, then there is no doubt that the land belongs to the Jews...

However if you want to stick to modern history, then after a fairly simple investigation you will discover that the territory so called "West Bank" has never been part of any state called Palestine. As a matter of fact, such state never existed. And if you want to abide by international laws, then you should describe those territories as "under dispute" at best.

Stealing really doesn't fit into the discourse. Unless of course you also agree to return Long Island to its original inhabitants...

Stefano, poor analogy. Those territories were taken according to 19th century rules, we are in the 21st century now. We know better. Israel and Russia are still acting according to those 19th century rules.

movogo, the land was stolen. It was taken by terrorizing the indigenous population in 1947-48 in order to force them to flee. It worked. It had to work in order to acquire land for a future Jewish state.

Rob, who is the aggressor? Who ended up with the land? Israel is the aggressor. The Arab militaries the Israelis faced were almost all of poor quality. They were never a match. Let's not pretend otherwise.
Don't forget thou shall not kill, or Thou shall not covet they neighbor goods!

Should anyone be building settlements on land stolen from someone else ?   What was it on those Tablets Moses Brought Down From the Mountain ?  Oh Yeah, I Remember now, they read, " THOU SHALT NOT STEAL !"

Read about Brooksley Born in Wikipedia, and see how she was treated by the Bush white house, and his advisers, could not override the GOP obstructionist.

Also, you seem to forget just how naive he was about the GOP. He thought he could get them to act in the best interest of the country, when they had made it their goal to make him a one term president.

The GOP did all they could to obstruct any legislation that might give him a better image with the public. Just read all their comments about the TARP, and the GM bailout. They are false and provable so, but they still keep repeating them.
They believe if they keep telling these lies they will be believed, and they are by the Obama haters, who do not care about the facts, but about their agenda.

Well, to summarize: If you think Obama is not essentially an economic conservative, you don't really read the news. For example, exactly what punishment did Wall St. get for the crap they pulled? How many new banking regulations are in place? Did Obama stimulate the economy in the bust or merely slowly roll back what Bush had done. Isn't "Obamacare" really in fact Romney care? (where's the single payer). Isn't his real gov spending in fact much less than Bush?

Obama is an economic conservative in every way shape and form.

Peter - The Democrats only had 60 votes in the Senate during Obama's first 2 years for the few months between the seating of Al Franken and the death of Ted Kennedy and the seating of Kennedy's successor and the election of Scott Brown. It is impossible to pass anything you want under those condition.

Why is it professor Krugman still blames the republicans or conservatives for
forR the Obama and
The progressives failed policies Obama could have done anything he wanted for the first two years of his presidency,which he knew since he told the republicans elections have consequences. Now five years later we have anemic growth more income inequality than ever and somehow the party out of power is responsible . Surely the responsibility for some of our problems are obamas fault or are you saying he has been so ineffective as to have had no impact on the country in the last five years.

"and every other right Israelis and other Western nations take for granted"

I count separation of church and state as a basic, taken-for-granted tenet of western democracy. The quasi theocracy that is Israel obviously doesn't, even though many Israelis do.
This is not a case of "whoever shows up in the nicest care gets to be Queen of the prom." It's a little more serious than that.

"The Palestinians are, literally, the opposite: controlled by a non-democratic leadership"

There was an election. Israel was horrified by who won. A coup was attempted, and that failed. After that, Israel and the US have demanded that Abbas extend his term repeatedly, because they fear a re-run of the election. Yet now they argue lack of that election they so do not want is reason not to deal with Abbas.

They have also threatened severe economic consequences if Abbas enters a serious deal with Hamas to re-unite the Palestinians. Yet now they argue they can't deal with them because they are not united.

The US rationalizes there will never be a better person to talk with than Abbas, yet conveys offers even he won't accept, and allows Israel to belittle him as someone with whom they cannot do a deal.

Excuses, all excuses, they don't even make sense.

This "debate" is so lopsided that one wonders how intelligent people like Ms. Friedman ever got suckered in. Mr. Gordis summarizes the conflict neatly when he points out that Israel is a free and open democracy where both its elected officials and an overwhelming majority of its citizens support the concept peaceful relations with a Palestinian state.

The Palestinians are, literally, the opposite: controlled by a non-democratic leadership which cannot bring itself to admit Israel exists. This Palestinian failure to accept reality harms them more than the Israelis.

Mr. Gordis quotes Golda Meir. Another relevant quote of hers is "the Palestinians never miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity." When Palestinians, and the rest of the Arab world drop their homophobia and misogyny, transform themselves into democracies, and embrace freedom of speech and freedom of religion, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly and every other right Israelis and other Western nations take for granted, the conflict will end, because there will nothing to fight about.
That is because the boundary is growing smaller and smaller.
The Palestinians are the only group seeking an independent state that has rejected independence because of a boundary dispute.

another famous lady once said that the palestinians never miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity...........

israel has been a peace partner and the arabs/palestinians never have

if israel is apartheid, what are the arab states? can a jew live and vote in the palestinian territories? oh, that's right, they don't vote there. can a jew live and vote in Iran, Iraq, Egypt,Jordan, Syria, Saudi Arabia? How about woman, even muslim women? who is apartheid?

To quote a famous First Lady on another issue, "Just say No" has been the mantra of the Palestinians since Modern Israel was accepted by the UN in 1948. perhaps peace will come when they learn to say "Yes."
Oh, my, you must agree to my generous offer that I only steal so much! What? You don't? Then since you don't agree, I take it all! Ha, too late, thanks!

The Palestinians have consistently refused what Israel was willing to offer.

Some say that proves they won't do any deal.

Others like me think that proves that even desperate people cannot be pushed as far as Israel tries to push the "deals" it offers.

Furthermore, by all his behavior, Netanyahu shows that if ever there were a chance of Palestinians accepting a deal, he'd demand more to ward off the risk of peace breaking out.

Mr. Eller asks, "What additional protection does Israel accrue that the Palestinians recognize Israel as a Jewish state? Would that not leave a whole lot of other countries which do recognize Israel as a state that do not also recognize it as a Jewish state?"

The issue, of course, is whether or not Palestinian Arabs are willing to accept Jewish sovereignty in a neighboring state. That has always been the crux of the conflict. When Palestinian Arabs aver that they are willing to recognize Israel as a state, but demand massive Arab immigration to that state, they are not accepting two states for two peoples, but two states for one people (and begrudgingly allowing one of those states to be called "Israel" for the time being). This is what Arafat, when speaking in Arabic even after Oslo, continued to refer to as his "demographic weapon."

For Israel to take the grave security risks inherent in ceding land to Palestinian Arabs, it must be convinced that the Palestinian Arabs have accepted the principle of two states for two peoples and that they are willing to sign a treaty that constitutes a permanent resolution of all claims between the two peoples.

Since it is the Palestinian Arab leaders who have clouded the meaning of recognizing Israel as a state, it is uniquely incumbent upon them to be explicit that they accept the notion of Jewish sovereignty.

How can the Times pretend to be presenting a neutral forum for a discussion when the anonymous introduction to the discussion begins with the biased assertion, "Israel’s expansion of settlements in the occupied territories has been an obstacle to the two-state solution"? It is self-evident that the principal obstacle to a two-state solution is the Palestinian refusal to recognize that of the two states, one will be Jewish.

Yes, growth of settlements may constrain the shape of negotiated borders, but they do not prevent the establishment of a viable Palestinian state. Granted, a larger Palestinian state might have been practical in 2000, when fewer Jews lived over the Green Line, if the Palestinians had agreed to the generous offer made to them then, instead of starting a second intifada. That is the price of Palestinian intransigence.

And so you would, once again, force Jews to live as a terrified minority wherever they live, hoping that nationalism and anti-Semitism does not again rear its monstrous head. Time and time and time again Jews have born the brunt of the world's inability to heed its better voices and time and time and time again, Jews have paid the price in Jewish blood.

The world is full of nations that, de jure or de facto, belong to one ethnic or religious group. The only time people seem to believe its bigoted, though, in the case of Israel. Israel is surrounded by nations that explicitly belong to one ethnic and religious group (Muslim Arabs) and who constantly are fighting to narrow its population even further (Sunni or Shi'ite). Why does no one object to them? Where is your righteous indignation and calls for boycotts of Turkey for their treatment the Kurds? Is it anti-Semitism or just ignorance?

We need only look to Europe to see the fallacy of this poisonous illusion. European countries are only welcoming of outsiders to a certain point, then their nationalist and xenophobic tendencies come to the front again. Whether its Switzerland restricting where its refugees may go, to the rise of the right in Northern Europe, to the frequently violent tensions between France and its Arab minority. Jews know...We know that it is only a matter of time before Europeans hate their resident minorities.

Your claim that having a Jewish state is the equivalent of having a "white" state is  intentionally dishonest.  A equal comparison would be an Islamic state.  There are currently a few dozen.  In addition Muslims are killing people on every continent on earth for more.  But yes, obviously the world should come together to make sure no other religious group gets a homeland except Muslims, who get as many as they want.   You call recognizing Israel as officially "Jewish" is "noxious".  Do you say the same about Turkey?

Paxson, I totally agree. Identifying a country with a religion would be intolerable. Imagine how the world would react if America put something like "In God We Trust" on their dollar bill. Or if there was such a thing as Church of England where the monarch was the Supreme Governor. Or if the Finnish constitution protected the Church of Finnland through a Church Act which could only be amended by the Church of Finnland. Or if the Greek Orthodox clergy were paid by the state.

Oh wait.

By the way ... Israeli law recognizes 5 religions, one of which is Islam, and has freedom of religion embedded in law. Israelis simply want one country in the world where their ethnic group is the majority. The historical reason for this should be obvious and understandable.

Why is this the country that is singled out for criticism?

"The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, recently reiterated his stance that recognizing Israel as a Jewish state is 'out of the question.' "

Of course it's out of the question. This should be a non-starter to all people, in regards to the identity of all nations. Defining an entire nation as belonging to one ethnic or religious group is fundamentally bigoted, an explicit rejection of the values and rights of the minority groups within its jurisdiction. Recognizing Israel as officially "Jewish" is as noxious as recognizing Sweden as officially "white," or Montana as officially "protestant." It reduces all members not in the majority to a diminished status as "lesser" members of society; as not belonging. It is incumbent on all nations with a respect for basic human rights not to force the Palestinians to reject this notion on their own--we should all be shouting it from the rooftops.

And why do right wing governments win elections in Israel?  Because every negotiated effort with the Palestinians has ended with the Palestinians being unable to finally sign off on a deal! (Camp David and Abbas-Ohlmert). In the aftermath of the Camp David breakdown - who's fault Bill Clinton ascribed to Arafat - the Palestinian began their suicide bombings.  Of course, Israel became more right leaning!  The cycle continues. While the settlement movement may be wrong in its own right, it is not the root cause for the failure of the peace process.
Exactly like Cuba became a shining example for a western democracy as a result of the US boycott, right? Oh I forgot, that one didn't quite work the way people expected...

Conceding for the sake of argument that 2/3 of Israelis would be willing to withdraw from most of the West Bank, the fact is that they continually elect governments of both right and left that continue the illegal settlement program.  Maybe its just a case of dedicated single-issue extremists able to impose their views on a more moderate majority. Whatever the reason, it seems clear to me that nothing would be more calculated to motivate this supposed silent majority to oppose their government's illegal activities than a program of boycott, sanctions and divestment that would threaten their economic welfare.
Well said.

We have all heard the saying that history repeats itself and Mr. Krugman is pointing out yet another example. But why does this happen? The reason is because human motivations are the same throughout history. These same motivations persist even though the conditions of technology and culture change. When crises arise, people don't examine the historical record and see what worked in the past and what didn't. They instead have a hysterical reaction and react emotionally. Hence, we keep making the same mistakes because our decisions are driven by these same motivations.

In the particular case of inflation, policy makers keep fighting it even though it's not there. They do this because the policy makers are the ones that have lots of money on the bank. They fear inflation more than anything because it robs their savings of buying power, which is their wealth. So when hard times come, they throw up the barriers to protect what is most emotionally significant to them, their personal assets in the bank. Whether or not jobs rise or fall does not concern them. Consequently, they will oppose anything we do today that *might* someday in the unforeseen future cause inflation. So nothing gets done.

Exactly what input, if any, did Palestinians have at the UN in the decision to create two states?

What is the legal authority of the United Nations to create, or determine the borders of, any nation?

What nation member of the United Nations grants the UN jurisdiction of what that nation's borders should be?

The UN in 1948   created  two states on Palestinian land it appropriated in violation of its own charter, Chapter one, Article 2, in which it ensures to all nations  the right of "self determination." No referendums were held; the Palestinians  were not even consulted. Small wonder they were miffed.

What about the thousand of people driven into refugee camps more than 60 years ago,  still sitting there today? Attacks on Arabs began before Arabs turned on Israel. Consider the citizens of the village of Deir Yessin, all murdered to make a statement to Arab citizens that they are no longer allowed to live on their own land. Perhaps you should have been there to protect those women and children from Israeli army guns.  Human beings lived in this region prior to a UN mandate. Maybe Laura is standing up and fighting for those who never had a chance.

In 1948, the United Nations created 2 states.. a Palestinian state and a Jewish state. The response of the arabs and the Palestinians was to immediately attack and destroy the Jewish state. If they had succeeded, would they have let any Jews still live in the middle east.

If the Palestinians want peace, then simply acknowledge the right of Israel to exist as a Jewish state. Then they have the ability to speak against the settlements. When Israel, in an attempt at peace, returned Gaza to the Palestinians, what they got in return was over 16,000 rockets… fired at civilian targets.

Those who push for a boycott, are blind, I do not see them railing against Korea, or Russia or Iran or Syria. THey pick Israel.. where Arabs can live and vote. In most Arab countries there are no votes, and they kill each other depending on whether they are Sunni or Shiite ( how do you tell the difference- by the way?)

Lara Friedman would have loved Neville Chamberlin, she calls for peace from the safety of her home in a country that is dedicated to tolerance and diversity. She and those in her organization threaten peace more than terrorists or dictators… because they will not stand and fight.

"Attempts by Ms. Friedman, of Americans (sic!) for Peace Now to support boycott is not considered a political step, but rather a failure of conscience on her part, at best hypocrisy and at worst reflects on her dealings with her own Jewishness."

Unbelievably weak. Play the ball, not the man.

"As Rabbi Dr. Gordis points out, if there is an agreement, there will be withdrawal to agreed upon borders. "

And as the rest of the world points out - no-one believes that any more in the face of the relentless creation of "facts on the ground".

B.D.S. is what's best for Israel in the long run.

You question Ms. Friedman's Jewishness? I question yours.

Can one bear false witness and still claim to be a Jew?

Can one steal, and still claim to be a Jew?

Can one ignore Rabbi Hillel's Golden Rule, and still claim to be a Jew?

I would hope that Ms. Friedman, from her perch of high morality in the US, would understand that the best way to convince Israelis to dig their heels in is to support a boycott of settlements, which is never just a boycott of settlements, in spite of her lofty convictions, but usually spills over to the legitimacy of Israel in all forms.
Ms. Friedman should also understand that attempts at boycott by Oxfam or the ASA or other groups are considered invidious by most Israelis, but part of the game, as it were. Attempts by Ms. Friedman, of Americans (sic!) for Peace Now to support boycott is not considered a political step, but rather a failure of conscience on her part, at best hypocrisy and at worst reflects on her dealings with her own Jewishness.
As Rabbi Dr. Gordis points out, if there is an agreement, there will be withdrawal to agreed upon borders. Most Israelis will support this. If Ms. Friedman wants to help harm those negotiations and cause damage, then by all means, boycott away.
Nigel--What could be better than one's best effort?  Nothing--that's what "best" is all about.  Your comment is nonsensical.

It might still be possible to acquire a quality education by paying attention to an old-fashioned "liberal arts" curriculum. Community colleges are staffed with competent instructional staff in core areas--language, foreign language, literature, history, basic sciences, art, music, etc. Moving on to a four year college and continuing a basic curriculum more or less focused on student interest should guarantee a B.A. worthy of consideration for graduate studies. But it's tough to choose coursework when future income is the criterion. That's how people wind up abandoning biology for accounting, or giving up art history for criminal justice courses.

On the contrary, it is movements like BDS that convince the Palestinians that if they just hold tight they will eventually get it all. Why compromise when you don't have to. They can always do it later.

It seems clear to me that Israeli military dominance locally, without any meaningful expectations or strings attached, precludes any peace or protection of Arabs' human rights. Israel has no reason to concede anything to anyone. As the United States provides the dominance,  if we truly desire more than the appearance of seeking a just  peace,  we must shift incentives accordingly. We might lay out a plan for gradually reduced military support until we see concrete progress. As matters stand, Israel steadily &  permanently settles the very land ostensibly under negotiation. It treats Palestinians in ways the international community rightly condemns,  and it frames all criticism or proposed accountability as racist. The time has come to acknowledge that "Never again"  does not justify any &  all deeds. Such an assumption risks arrogance, abuse,  &  even evil.

And when Ehud Barak and Ehud Olmert negotiated settlements that gave the Palestinians 96% of the West Bank where were the Palestinians when it came time to sign on the dotted line?
All of this would now be past history.
One comment said that Israel is not a democracy because Ha-Aretz writes that it is not so. If we are already quoting ha-Aretz then required reading is the op-ed of Prof. Shelomo Avineri on how Abbas will pull out at the last minute.
Political pundits in Israel state that Mr. Netanyahu will sign on in Washington. If so. let's see the Palestinians do the same.

The only time recently a "negotiated settlement was within reach" was when Pres Clinton tried to twist the arms of (then leaders) Barak and Arafat into signing a peace agreement. Barak pretty much agreed, while Arafat rushed home to start the 2nd Intifadah (uprising).

The settlements have been used by the Palestinians as an excuse to walk away from the negotiations, not as a reason not to sign an agreement... We're not close to signing an agreement, and the reasons are far from being the "settlements". Read about my views why at: http://bit.ly/1hFqhfB

Ian:  your knowledge of the Israeli-Arab conflict is on par with your knowledge of Marx Brothers trivia.  It was not Groucho but Chico who spoke the line.  As to settlements, I would love to hear the real explanation for why they are such a problem.  The Oslo Accords never prohibited any building and one would think that if the Palestinians were serious about setting up a peaceful state, and if they were really so concerned, they would have found a way to compromise on some of their issues.  You know the one I mean: their refusal to recognize Israel as the national homeland of the Jewish people, in defiance of international law as set down in the Mandate for Palestine in 1922 and which still governs.

Where does Daniel Gordis get the idea that anyone any longer trusts any of Netanyahu's assurances? In Groucho Marx's immortal line, "Who are you going to believe, me or your own eyes?" As Lara points out, we have all seen with our own eyes that every time a negotiated settlement seems within reach it is dashed against the ground by the announcement of a speed-up of settlements.

Re. to PY.
Point by point:
So "Left-leaning" disqualifies a newspaper from having something to say in this debate? Their opinion is to be dismissed out of hand? I'm a bit surprised PY reads the left-leaning NYTimes.
I know many Israeli citizens who describe their country as an apartheid state. A democracy in which a substantial part of the population is denied the right to vote is about as democratic as ancient Athens. A true democracy would not call itself a Jewish State. It would call itself a state.
Boycotts? Russia is being threatened with a boycott. Iran is currently being boycotted. As are Venezuela, Cuba, North Korea, et al. Do boycotts work? Of that I am not sure.

These things having been said, the situation is not a good-guy vs. bad-guy situation. It's a peace or no peace situation. Both sides have acted and continue to act petulantly. There is not a choice to be made about who is right or wrong. Solomon's option will not draw out the chosen people and expose the frauds. They are all chosen frauds.
If they want peace they will have to stop throwing rocks and building settlements and counting casualties. Unfortunately human beings remember too much of the wrong stuff and too little of the important stuff.
Wash, rinse, repeat.

I cannot comment on what Canadians chose to do. As a U.S. citizen my vote is for absolute neutrality with regard to all disputes within nations and between nations in the Middle East -- indeed in all of Asia. Taking sides and becoming involved, as recent history as proven repeatedly, is costly and painful not only for the U.S. citizenry, but also for Asians whose problems are simply further complicated by our inept involvement.

Walter: with all respect, the tired argument is the one about the settlements violating international law. Consider the following facts and then you can decide. The League of Nations in 1922 established the Mandate for Palestine which recognized the area as the national homeland of the Jews and set it aside for their close settlement on the land. That land included present day Israel, Jordan, Gaza, West Bank - a 1950 coinage by Jordan for the land it seized in the 1948-49 war, you might find it of interest that the 1947 partition resolution referred to Samaria and Judea. The Mandate established the basis for settlement under international law and the UN Charter (Art. 80) specifically prohibited any changes to the mandates established by the League of Nations. So, no General Assembly resolution (including the partition resolution which the Arabs rejected anyway) or Security Council resolution could alter the Jews rights to the land. It really doesn't matter how many partisans pretend otherwise. As a legal matter, there is no "Palestinian land" as such since there never was a Palestinian sovereign. You may not like it but those are the facts.
Think of the peace process this way: Israel is being asked - uniquely among all other nations - to surrender lands that international law recognizes as belonging to it. And in this regard, I am not relying on the secondary ground that its land taken in a defensive war as Jordan attacked in 1967 and was not pre-empted as was Egypt.

Daniel Gordis again brings out the tired argument that the West has to support the only true democracy in the region. Whether the true democracy claim holds is an open question - many writers in Haaretz do not agree, and the claims that is Israel is an apartheid state are getting louder and louder. Be that is it may, the main argument against the settlements is that they violate international law, and the European Union is committed not to whitewash such violations on the grounds of political arguments. Since the EU is Israel's main trading partner any boycott or other sanction is likely to cut deeply, and the boycott is starting at the highest levels already.

Karen, I agree with much that you write, with one exception. It's unfair to pair Geithner and Bernanke. Geithner, who bore responsibility for fiscal policy, showed tremendous concern for the well-being of Wall Street, and virtually no concern for Main Street. Fiscal policy largely went missing after Wall Street was rescued, but for a comparatively modest stimulus. Geithner did precious little for most Americans, and his appointment was a missed opportunity for the Obama presidency.

Bernanke, on the other hand, pulled out the stops with respect to monetary policy, while keeping the Fed comparatively united. That the U.S. economy kept afloat (granted, precariously so) post 2008 is due to Bernanke's leadership. We owe Bernanke a debt of gratitude.
